026package com.ibm.streams.operator.samples.patterns;
027
028import java.util.HashSet;
029import java.util.Iterator;
030import java.util.LinkedList;
031import java.util.Queue;
032import java.util.Set;
033import java.util.concurrent.Callable;
034import java.util.concurrent.ExecutionException;
035import java.util.concurrent.Future;
036import java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit;
037
038import com.ibm.streams.operator.AbstractOperator;
039import com.ibm.streams.operator.OperatorContext;
040import com.ibm.streams.operator.StreamingData.Punctuation;
041import com.ibm.streams.operator.StreamingInput;
042import com.ibm.streams.operator.Tuple;
043import com.ibm.streams.operator.model.Parameter;
044
045/**
046 * Abstract pattern class for an operator that consumes tuples and does not
047 * produce an output stream. Incoming tuples are processed in batches, driven by
048 * the size of the batch and a timeout. A batch is processed when it reaches at
049 * least getBatchSize() or at least getBatchTimeout() time have passed since the
050 * first tuple was added to the batch.
051 * <P>
052 * The batch is processed by the processBatch provided by a concrete sub-class.
053 * <BR>
054 * Processing of the batch is asynchronous with incoming tuples.
055 * </P>
056 * <P>
057 * A batch size of 1 (the default) is not treated specially, in this case each
058 * incoming tuple may start batch processing meaning that all processing of the
059 * tuple in processBatch() is handled asynchronously with other tuple arrival.
060 * </P>
061 * <P>
062 * Note that there is no requirement to use this class to implement a sink style
063 * operator. <BR>
064 * </P>
065 */
066public abstract class TupleConsumer extends AbstractOperator {
067
068    /**
069     * A batched tuple representing the tuple and the port it arrived on.
070     */
071    public static class BatchedTuple {
072        private final StreamingInput<Tuple> stream;
073        private final Tuple tuple;
074
075        BatchedTuple(StreamingInput<Tuple> stream, Tuple tuple) {
076            this.stream = stream;
077            this.tuple = tuple;
078        }
079
080        /**
081         * Get the port the tuple arrived on.
082         * 
083         * @return The stream the tuple arrived on.
084         */
085        public final StreamingInput<Tuple> getStream() {
086            return stream;
087        }
088
089        /**
090         * Get the tuple.
091         * 
092         * @return The tuple.
093         */
094        public final Tuple getTuple() {
095            return tuple;
096        }
097    }
098
099    protected Queue<BatchedTuple> batch;
100
101    private int batchSize = 1;
102
103    private long batchTimeout = 0;
104
105    private TimeUnit batchTimeoutUnit;
106
107    private boolean preserveOrder = true;
108
109    /**
110     * Initialize this operator. Called once before any tuples are processed.
111     * Sub-classes must call super.initialize(context) to correctly setup an
112     * operator.
113     */
114    @Override
115    public synchronized void initialize(OperatorContext context)
116            throws Exception {
117        super.initialize(context);
118
119        batch = newBatch();
120    }
121
122    private Queue<BatchedTuple> newBatch() {
123        return new LinkedList<BatchedTuple>();
124    }
125
126    private Future<Object> activeTimeout;
127
128    /**
129     * Process incoming tuples by adding them to the current batch
130     * and submitting the batch for execution if required.
131     */
132    @Override
133    public synchronized void process(StreamingInput<Tuple> stream, Tuple tuple)
134            throws Exception {
135
136        batch.add(new BatchedTuple(stream, tuple));
137
138        if (batch.size() < getBatchSize()) {
139            if (getBatchTimeout() == 0)
140                return;
141            
142            if (activeTimeout != null && !activeTimeout.isDone())
143                return;
144            
145            // If we have a timeout for batch submission then the
146            // first time a tuple gets added to the batch create a
147            // timeout event to process the batch in case no more tuples come in.
148            {
149                activeTimeout = getOperatorContext()
150                        .getScheduledExecutorService().schedule(
151                                new Callable<Object>() {
152                                    public Object call() throws Exception {
153                                        submitBatch(false);
154                                        return null;
155                                    }
156                                }, getBatchTimeout(), getBatchTimeoutUnit());
157            }
158            return;
159        }
160
161        submitBatch(false);
162
163    }
164    
165    /**
166     * Process any final punctuation by flushing the batch
167     * and waiting for all the work to complete.
168     */
169    @SuppressWarnings("incomplete-switch")
170    public void processPunctuation(StreamingInput<Tuple> port, Punctuation mark)
171          throws Exception {
172        // No need to call super.processPunctuation because that just forwards
173        // window punctuation marks to the output ports and this operator
174        // doesn't support output ports.
175        
176        // If a final marker comes in then need to flush out any remaining tuples.
177        if (mark != Punctuation.FINAL_MARKER)
178            return;
179        switch (mark) {
180        case WINDOW_MARKER:
181            break;
182        case FINAL_MARKER:
183            flushTuples(port);
184            break;
185        }
186    }
187    
188    /**
189     * Process all batched tuples from this port.
190     */
191    private void flushTuples(StreamingInput<Tuple> port) {
192        
193        outer: for (;;) {
194            
195            // Submit any remaining batch tuples.
196            submitBatch(false);
197            
198            // Need to wait for a current batch to complete
199            // otherwise it would be a busy wait calling
200            // submitBatch().
201            batchWait();
202       
203            synchronized (this) {
204                // See if we have any tuples left
205                // from this port.
206                for (BatchedTuple bt : batch) {
207                    // At least one, need to continue submitting.
208                    if (bt.getStream() == port)
209                        continue outer;
210                }
211                
212                // No tuples in the current batch,
213                // but need to ensure that all other
214                // batches are complete.
215                if (batchesComplete())
216                    break;
217            }
218        }
219    }
220    
221    /**
222     * Discard all batched tuples from this port.
223     * @param port
224     */
225    // TODO: Remove this code. Used by RESET_MARKER, but that punctuation
226    // is no longer exposed to Java code.
227    /* private void discardTuples(StreamingInput<Tuple> port) {
228        for (;;) {
229            synchronized (this) {
230                for (Iterator<BatchedTuple> it = batch.iterator(); it.hasNext();) {
231                    BatchedTuple bt = it.next();
232                    if (bt.getStream() == port)
233                        it.remove();
234                }
235                
236                if (batchesComplete())
237                    return;
238            }
239            batchWait();
240        }
241    } */
242    
243    /**
244     * Set of the background tasks that have been kicked off
245     * for batch processing (calling processBatch()).
246     * 
247     */
248    private final Set<Future<?>> activeBatches = new HashSet<Future<?>>();
249    
250    /**
251     * Test to see if all the batches are complete.
252     */
253    private synchronized boolean batchesComplete() {
254        boolean allComplete = true;
255        for (Iterator<Future<?>> i = activeBatches.iterator(); i.hasNext(); )
256        {
257            Future<?> batch = i.next();
258            if (batch.isDone())
259                i.remove();
260            else
261                allComplete = false;
262        }
263        return allComplete;
264    }
265    
266    /**
267     * Wait for any outstanding batch item.
268     */
269    private void batchWait() {
270        Future<?> waitBatch = null;
271        
272        synchronized (this) {
273            for (Iterator<Future<?>> i = activeBatches.iterator(); i.hasNext();) {
274                Future<?> batch = i.next();
275                if (!batch.isDone())
276                {
277                    waitBatch = batch;
278                    break;
279                }
280            }
281        }
282        if (waitBatch != null)
283            try {
284                waitBatch.get();
285            } catch (InterruptedException e) {
286                ;
287            } catch (ExecutionException e) {
288                ;
289            }
290    }
291    
292
293    /**
294     * Submit a batch of tuples to be processed by the sub-classes processBatch
295     * using a asynchronous task.
296     * @param submitter True if this is being called from a task that itself was
297     * created by submitBatch.
298     */
299    private synchronized void submitBatch(boolean submitter) {
300        // We are processing so remove any existing timeout
301        if (activeTimeout != null) {
302            activeTimeout.cancel(false);
303            activeTimeout = null;
304        }
305
306        // Async threads may mean this is called just after
307        // another submit batch so if nothing to do, just complete.
308        if (batch.isEmpty())
309            return;
310        
311        boolean allComplete = batchesComplete();
312        
313        // Limit the number of outstanding tasks.
314        //if (!allComplete && activeBatches.size() > taskThreadold )
315        //    return;
316
317        // If we are the submitter then even if preserveOrder is true we can continue
318        // because we must be the only submitter.
319        if (!submitter && preserveOrder) {
320            // If we are preserving order then we cannot
321            // have more than one processBatch() request outstanding
322            // as it would be non-deterministic which one ran first,
323            // thus leading to processing tuples out of order.
324            if (!allComplete)
325                return;
326        }
327
328        final Queue<BatchedTuple> asyncBatch = batch;
329        batch = newBatch();
330        activeBatches.add(getOperatorContext().getScheduledExecutorService()
331                .submit(new Callable<Object>() {
332                    public Object call() throws Exception {
333                        
334                        boolean addLeftovers = processBatch(asyncBatch);
335
336                        synchronized (TupleConsumer.this) {
337                            // Add remaining elements back into the queue
338                            // placing them at the front.
339                            if (addLeftovers && !asyncBatch.isEmpty()) {
340                                asyncBatch.addAll(batch);
341                                batch = asyncBatch;
342                            }
343
344                            if (batch.size() < getBatchSize())
345                                return null;
346
347                            // Will need to submit a batch if we just added
348                            // enough tuples to exceed the batch size, or
349                            // we are preserving order and enough tuples
350                            // arrived while this batch was being processed.
351                            submitBatch(true);
352
353                        }
354                        return null;
355                    }
356                }));
357    }
358
359    /**
360     * Get the batch size.
361     * 
362     * @return Current batch size, defaults to 1 if setBatchSize() has not been
363     *         called.
364     */
365    public final synchronized int getBatchSize() {
366        return batchSize;
367    }
368
369    /**
370     * Set the current batch size. If least batchSize tuples are currently batched
371     * then batch processing will be initiated asynchronously.
372     * 
373     * @param batchSize
374     *            New batch size, must be one or greater.
375     */
376    @Parameter(optional=true,
377            description="Set the batch size.")
378    public synchronized void setBatchSize(int batchSize) {
379        if (batchSize <= 0)
380            throw new IllegalArgumentException(
381                    "Sink batchSize must be not be zero or negative.");
382
383        this.batchSize = batchSize;
384        
385        // When called via the Parameter annotation
386        // there will not batch set up.
387        if (batch != null) {
388            if (batch.size() >= batchSize)
389                submitBatch(false);
390        }
391    }
392
393    /**
394     * Get the batch timeout value.
395     * 
396     * @return Current batch timeout, defaults to 0 (no timeout) if
397     *         setBatchTimeout has not been called.
398     */
399    public synchronized final long getBatchTimeout() {
400        return batchTimeout;
401    }
402
403    /**
404     * Set the batch timeout. The batch timeout is the amount of time the
405     * operator will wait after the first tuple in the batch before processing
406     * the batch. For example with a batch size of 100 and a timeout of two
407     * seconds a batch will be processed when whichever comes first out of 100
408     * tuples are in the batch or 2 seconds have passed since the first tuple
409     * was added. <BR>
410     * This method should be made at initialization time, within the initialize
411     * method. Calling it once tuples are being received and batched may have
412     * unpredictable effects.
413     * 
414     * A timeout of 0 means no timeout.
415     * 
416     * @param batchTimeout
417     *            Timeout value
418     * @param unit
419     *            Unit of the timeout value
420     */
421    public final synchronized void setBatchTimeout(long batchTimeout,
422            TimeUnit unit) {
423        this.batchTimeout = batchTimeout;
424        this.batchTimeoutUnit = unit;
425    }
426
427    /**
428     * Process a batch of tuples.
429     * 
430     * This call is made asynchronously with incoming tuples and tuples that
431     * arrive after this processing was initiated will not be added to set
432     * defined by the passed in collection batch. Such tuples will be processed
433     * in a future batch. <BR>
434     * The expected case is that this method will process all tuples in the
435     * batch, but a mechanism exists to allow a subset of tuples to be processed
436     * in a future batch. If this method returns true any tuples remaining in
437     * the passed in collection are added into a future batch. If false is
438     * returned then it is assumed that all tuples have been processed and none
439     * will processed in the future. <BR>
440     * No assumptions should be made about the number of tuples in the passed in
441     * collection batch, it may be less than, equal to or greater than the
442     * current batch size. <BR>
443     * If tuple arrival order is not being preserved then this method may be
444     * called concurrently by multiple threads (with different batches) and thus
445     * needs to be thread safe.
446     * 
447     * @param batch
448     *            Batch of tuples to be processed, its contents are not modified
449     *            by any incoming tuples.
450     * 
451     * @return True process any tuples left in batch in a future batch, false no
452     *         tuples are added back for future processing.
453     */
454    protected abstract boolean processBatch(Queue<BatchedTuple> batch)
455            throws Exception;
456
457    /**
458     * Set if order of tuples is preserved in the batch and in the calls to
459     * processBatch. If set to true then no concurrent calls will be made to
460     * processBatch. <BR>
461     * This method should be made at initialization time, within the initialize
462     * method. Calling it once tuples are being received and batched may have
463     * unpredictable effects.
464     * 
465     * @param preserveOrder
466     *            True to preserve order, false to not care about ordering.
467     */
468    public final synchronized void setPreserveOrder(boolean preserveOrder) {
469        this.preserveOrder = preserveOrder;
470    }
471
472    /**
473     * True if arrival order is to be preserved when processing tuples.
474     * @return True if arrival order is to be preserved.
475     */
476    public synchronized final boolean isPreserveOrder() {
477        return preserveOrder;
478    }
479
480    public synchronized TimeUnit getBatchTimeoutUnit() {
481        return batchTimeoutUnit;
482    }
483}
